qas.question: How do quarter wave elements act in relation to a series relevant electrical element?
What frequency develops a current peak?
How would you describe a current that has maximum efficiency?
What could be the best possible output versus input ratio?

context: The quarter-wave elements <a0_0>imitate<a0_0/> a series-resonant electrical element due to the standing wave present along the conductor. At the <a1_0>resonant frequency<a1_0/>, the standing wave has a current peak and voltage node (minimum) at the feed. In electrical terms, this means the element has <a2_0>minimum reactance<a2_0/>, generating the maximum current for minimum voltage. This is the ideal situation, because it produces the maximum output for the minimum input, producing the highest possible efficiency. Contrary to an ideal (<a3_0>lossless<a3_0/>) series-resonant circuit, a finite resistance remains (corresponding to the relatively small voltage at the feed-point) due to the antenna's radiation resistance as well as any actual electrical losses.
